questions.question: Which of the following conditions is least likely to present with diplopia?
questions.explanation: Latent squint does not always present with diplopia.Heterophoria (Latent squint) is a condition in which the tendency of the eyes to deviate is keptlatent by fusion. When the influence of fusion is removed, the visual axis of one eye deviates away.Types:· Esophoria-convergent•Exophoria-divergent• Hyperphoria-deviation upwards⚫ Hypophoria-deviation downwards••Cyclophoria-rotation around AP axisSymptoms:•Usually asymptomatic-compensated type.• In cases where there are symptoms-decompensated type• Headache• Eye ache•Photophobia• Intermittent diplopia (only under fatigue - temporarily)

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common type of squint seen in children?
questions.explanation: Accommodative esotropia is the most common type of squint seen in children.476Most common type of squint overall: accommodative esotropiaSecond most common overall: congenital/Infantile esotropiaMost common type of exotropia: primary exotropia

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding comitant squint?

options.D: No co-relation between primary and secondary deviations

questions.explanation: In comitant squint (concomitant), the primary deviation is equal to the secondary deviation.Primary deviation = Deviation of the squinting eyeSecondary deviation = Deviation of the normal eye under cover when the patient fixes withthe squinting eye.In incomitant (paralytic and restrictive squint), secondary deviation > primary deviation due toHerring's Law of equal innervation.

questions.question: A mother noticed that her child has had malaligned eyes since birth but she couldn't affordtreatment due to financial constraints. She now presents at 2-months of age and the child hasthe following finding on examination. An ophthalmoscopic examination under full cycloplegiareveals no abnormalities in refraction and media. Cranial nerves are intact. Which of thefollowing statements is true regarding this condition?465

options.A: Angle of deviation is large and constant.
options.B: Amblyopia develops in 90 % of the cases.
options.C: It is associated with latent vertical nystagmus.
options.D: Correction by spectacles is the treatment of choice.

questions.explanation: The age at presentation, esotropia, no refractory error, no media opacities, and no cranial nervepalsies suggest a diagnosis of essential infantile esotropia. The angle of deviation in infantileesotropia is fairly large (> 30°) and constant.Infantile esotropia, also known as non-accommodative esotropia is the most common type ofcongenital esotropia.Clinical features:• Comitant convergent squint•..Age of onset- 1 to 2 months•Angle of deviation- large and constantAmblyopia- develops in 25-40% of cases• Associations include:• Inferior oblique overaction• Dissociated vertical deviation (70%)• Latent horizontal nystagmusTreatment:•Surgery-treatment of choice• Amblyopia correction measures: Patching of normal eye•Recession of both medial recti• Timing: Preferably before 1 year477

questions.question: A surgeon decides to resect a part of a muscle while operating on a case of strabismus. Thisaction would lead to which of the following?

options.D: No change in strength of the muscle

questions.explanation: In squint surgery, muscle resection leads to the strengthening of the muscle.The main types of procedure in squint surgery are as follows:• Weakening to decrease the effective strength of action of a muscle.• Recession slackens a muscle by moving it away from its insertion. It can be performed on anymuscle except the superior oblique.• Disinsertion (or myectomy) involves detaching a muscle from its insertion without reattachment.It is most commonly used to weaken an overacting inferior oblique muscle.⚫ Posterior fixation suture: The principle of this (Faden) procedure is to suture the muscle belly tothe sclera posteriorly so as to decrease the pull of the muscle in its field of action without affectingthe eye in the primary position.••Strengthening, to enhance the pull of a muscle.Resection shortens a muscle to enhance its effective pull. It is suitable only for the rectus muscle.Tucking of a muscle or its tendon is usually confined to the enhancement of the action of thesuperior oblique muscle.• Advancement of the muscle nearer to the limbus can be used to enhance the action of apreviously recessed rectus muscle.•Vector adjustment procedures have the primary aim of altering the direction of muscle action.•⚫ Transposition refers to the relocation of one or more extraocular muscles to substitute for theaction of an absent or severely deficient muscle. The most common indication is severe lateralrectus weakness due to acquired palsy of the 6th cranial nerve palsy.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding accommodative esotropia?

options.A: It is the most common type of squint.
options.B: Miotics are used as the treatment strategy in the high AC/A ratio
options.C: It is associated with high myopia.
options.D: Refractive type can be fully corrected by use of spectacles.466

questions.explanation: Accommodative esotropia is associated with a high degree of hypermetropia (+4 to +7 D).Accommodative esotropia is the most common type of squint. Typically presents around 2 to 3years of age.Types:• Refractive• Associated with high hypermetropia••Fully correctable by spectaclesNon-refractive type• Abnormal accommodative convergence/accommodation (AC/A) ratio•• Fully corrected by bifocal glasses• Miotics useful in cases where glasses are unsuitable• Echothiophate causes iris cyst478• Prevention of iris cysts- Phenylephrine drops• Mixed typeThe accommodative convergence/accommodation (AC/A) ratio is defined as the amount ofconvergence measured in prism diopters per unit (diopter) change in accommodation.The image below shows accommodative esotropia with and without correction.

questions.question: Which of the following is the best line of treatment in a 3-year-old child presenting with arecent onset of 15-degree accommodative esotropia?
questions.explanation: The best line of treatment in accommodative esotropia is a refractive correction.Esotropia for distance is corrected by the treatment of hypermetropia: convex glassesEsotropia for near is corrected by +3DS lens.479Algorithm for the management of accommodative esotropia is as follows:• R: Refractive correction: Glasses/Miotics⚫O: Orthoptics/Occlusion: for amblyopia•O: Operative correction: for non-accommodative component• P: Prism correction: for remaining error

questions.question: Charlie, a 5-year-old boy with crossed eyes received his first eye exam from a primary careophthalmologist. Examination, including cycloplegic refraction and dilated fundus exam,resulted in diagnoses of constant right esotropia, and amblyopia in the right eye. By what ageshould his amblyopia be corrected?
questions.explanation: Strabismic amblyopia should be corrected before 8 years of age.The sensitive period during which acuity of an amblyopic eye can be improved is usually up to 7-8years in strabismic amblyopia and maybe longer (into the teens) for anisometropic amblyopiawhen a good binocular function is present.In the absence of an organic lesion, a difference in best-corrected visual acuity (VA) of two Snellenlines or more (or >1 log unit) is indicative of amblyopia.Treatment of amblyopia:• Occlusion of the normal eye, to encourage the use of the amblyopic eye, is the most effectivetreatment.•Penalization, in which vision in the normal eye is blurred with atropine, is an alternativemethod.

questions.question: A 5-year-old female patient presented for her first complete eye examination after a schoolvision screening found unequal visual acuity. Her parents have not noted any eye problems.Visual acuity in the right eye was 20/20 and the left eye is 20/80. The rest of the examinationwas unremarkable and glasses were prescribed. She was diagnosed with anisometrichyperopia and amblyopia of the left eye when her visual acuity at a return appointment wasfound to be 20/20 RE and 20/60 LE at a distance while wearing her new glasses. What is thetreatment of choice?
questions.explanation: Occlusion of the normal eye is the treatment of choice for amblyopia.Amblyopia is an uncorrectable decrease in vision in one or both eyes with no apparent structuralabnormality seen to explain it. It is a diagnosis of exclusion. Generally, a difference of two lines ormore on an eye chart test of visual acuity between the two eyes or a best-corrected vision of 20/30or worse would be defined as amblyopia. For example, our patient has 20/20 vision with the righteye and only 20/80 with the left and the left eye even after best-corrected vision couldn't achieve<20/30 vision, the left eye is said to be amblyopic.Clinical features:• Decreased contrast sensitivity• Diminution of visionSunglass effect- brightness is less compared to the normal eye• Crowding phenomenon- slipping of imagesTreatment of choice:• Occlusion of the normal eye (4 to 6 hours/day) using patches.• Penalization: Blurring of vision using atropine.480Prism correction is not the right treatment as the child doesn't have strabismus.

questions.question: 467A 3-year-old child presents with a right convergent squint of 6 months duration. Choose themost appropriate treatment strategy.

options.A: Immediate surgical correction followed by amblyopia therapy
options.B: Proper refractive correction, amblyopia therapy followed by surgical correction
options.C: Prescription of spectacles and defer surgery until 5 years
options.D: Botulinum toxin injection followed by occlusion therapy

questions.explanation: The appropriate management in this case would be proper refractive correction, amblyopiatherapy followed by surgical correctionThe algorithm for management of accommodative squint is as follows:• R: Refractive correction: Glasses/Miotics⚫O: Orthoptics/Occlusion: For amblyopia• O: Operative correction: For non-accommodative component• P: Prism correction: For remaining error

questions.question: In which of the following conditions should an ophthalmologist prescribe miotics?
questions.explanation: Miotics are used in the management of accommodative esotropia.The use of miotics in convergent strabismus is based on the peripheral spasm of accommodationcaused by the drug. The accommodation triad involves convergence. An increased accommodativeeffort increases the amount of convergence. Pilocarpine would produce accommodation spasmand eliminate the accommodative convergence that would otherwise occur when the patient looksat a near object. It is useful in cases of an abnormal AC/A ratio as in, accommodative esotropia.

questions.question: A patient complains of difficulty in climbing down the stairs due to double vision. Onexamination, you notice his right eye has deviated upward and the deviation becomes morepronounced on the left gaze. The remaining extraocular movements are intact. Which nerve ismost likely involved?
questions.explanation: The affected nerve in the given clinical scenario is the right trochlear nerve.The right trochlear nucleus actually innervates the left superior oblique and vice versa. However,the nerve decussates at the midbrain at the level of the inferior colliculus. So, lesions ofthe trochlear nucleus lead to contralateral palsy. While that of trochlear nerve peripherally lead toipsilateral palsy.In this patient, the right-sided symptoms could be due to a lesion in the right trochlearnerve (ipsilateral) or left trochlear nucleus (contralateral). He complains of diplopia whileclimbing down the stairs because the normal eye can look down but the paralytic eye has deviated.There is also a limitation of depression due to superior oblique palsy, and hence the eye isdeviated upward due to overaction of the inferior oblique. The obliques exert maximum force inan adducted position and hence the deviation becomes more prominent on the left gaze when theright eye is adducted.

questions.question: An eleven-year-old girl presented with a history of squint and poor vision. She had visualacuities of 6/24 and counting fingers in her right and left eyes respectively. There was a lefthypotropia in the primary position of gaze with associated marked restriction of elevation inadduction and a positive forced duction test. A diagnosis of Brown syndrome was made. Thepathology involves which of the following muscles?
questions.explanation: Brown syndrome occurs due to mechanical restriction caused by a congenitally tight superioroblique sheath or by the impaired movement of the superior oblique tendon through the trochlea.It may be acquired in some cases.Contracture of the superior oblique leads to restriction of its antagonistic muscle, the inferioroblique and that is why the patient presents with absence of elevation in adduction.

questions.question: Brown's syndrome simulates which muscle palsy?
questions.explanation: 486Brown's superior oblique tendon sheath syndrome simulates palsy of inferior oblique muscle. Inboth of these cases, there is a limited elevation of the eye in adduction.Brown's superior oblique tendon sheath syndrome is a cause of restrictive squint. The forcedduction test is positive.Differential diagnoses of Brown's syndrome:••Inferior oblique palsy- differentiated by a positive head-tilt test (negative in Brown's syndrome)and a negative forced duction test (positive in Brown's syndrome)•Primary superior oblique overaction- differentiated by negative forced duction test (Positive inBrown's syndrome)

questions.question: Identify the condition.472
questions.explanation: The given image classically depicts an A pattern esotropia. Relative convergence on upgaze(esotropia increases on upgaze) is a feature of A-pattern esotropia.A or V pattern heterotropia:• "V" or "A" patterns occur when the relative contributions of the superior rectus and inferioroblique to elevation, or of the inferior rectus and superior oblique to depression, are abnormal,resulting in the derangement of the balance of their horizontal vectors in up and downgaze.• Oblique muscle dysfunction is the commonest• "V" pattern is said to be significant when the difference between upgaze and downgaze is ≥15 A.• "A" pattern is considered significant if the difference between upgaze and downgaze is ≥10 A.The image below shows A and V pattern heterotropia

questions.question: A patient presents with left-sided head tilt which on straightening leads to right hypotropia.This increases on dextroversion and right head tilt. Paralysis of which of the followingmuscles is involved?
questions.explanation: ARROMARROWV487Right superior rectus palsy is the cause for the given clinical scenario.The three-step test, also known as the Parks-Bielschowsky three-step test, is a diagnostic test usedto identify which muscle is paralyzed in the case of an acquired hypertropia. This method uses thecover-uncover test, with or without the Maddox rod to measure the amount of deviation indifferent head positions.The three-step test may also be used to diagnose the less common inferior oblique or verticalrectus muscle palsy. It is designed for the diagnosis of a single paretic vertical muscle and isunreliable when there are multiple paretic muscles or in restrictive strabismus. This test may alsohelp in identifying if a superior rectus palsy is true or simulated in a patient with an inhibitionalpalsy of the contralateral antagonist.Using the three-step test in the above clinical scenario:Step 1. Which eye is hypotrophic?The eye hypotrophic in the primary position is the right eye. The paretic muscles can be right eyeelevator or left eye depressor.•Right superior rectus•• Right inferior oblique• Left inferior rectus• Left superior obliqueStep 2. Does the hypotropia increase in the right gaze or left gaze?The hypotropia increases in right gaze.Therefore, the paretic muscle must be either (1) one of the muscles whose primary action iselevating the right eye on the right gaze, or (2) one of the muscles whose primary action isdepressing the left eye in the right gaze. The left inferior oblique and the right superior rectusboth have a primary action of elevation in right gaze. Therefore, one of these muscles could be theparetic muscle. Likewise, the left superior oblique and the right inferior rectus have a primaryaction of depression in the right gaze and could be paretic. But since the left inferior oblique andthe right inferior rectus did not meet step 1, they can be eliminated from the possible pareticmuscles. This leaves us:• Left superior oblique•• Right superior rectusStep 3. Does the hypotropia increase in the right head tilt or left head tilt?The hypotropia increases in the right head tilt. If the deviation increases on right head tilt anddecreases on left head tilt, as it does in this example patient, then the right superior rectus isimplicated as the paretic culprit.488
